newsitem.title: UK: Dollar softer in Europe, tracks weak U.S. assets.
newsitem.headline: Dollar softer in Europe, tracks weak U.S. assets.

text.p: The dollar opened softer in Europe after a four-day Easter break with the market nervous after sharp falls in U.S asset markets, said analysts.
The Dow industrials index lost 157 points to 6,583 on Monday after shedding 140 points last Thursday, for an aggregate 4.3 percent decline.
"It looks as if the Fed will be tightening again...But the buoyancy in the U.S. economy argues for a firmer dollar," said Tony Norfield, treasury economist at ABN AMRO.
He said the dollar was likely to remain nervous ahead of key economic indicators on Tuesday.
Norfield said U.S. data, due later on Tuesday, could reinforce market expectations of higher U.S. rates to cool the economy.
U.S. February leading indicators, construction spending and March National Association of Purchasing Management (NAPM) are due at 1400 GMT.
The key NAPM index is forecast to be stronger at 54.6 vs 53.1 in February.
At 0753 the dollar was at 1.6670/75 marks vs 1.6772/77 marks in late Europe on Thursday. Against the yen, the dollar was steady at 123.48/3.53 vs 123.48/53 in late Europe on Thursday.
While a strong NAPM could knock the U.S. unit, as the market anticipates the effect of higher rates on U.S. stock and bonds markets, the effect on the dollar should be short-lived.
"I think any negative impact will be short-lived," said Chris Turner, currency strategist at BZW, adding that medium and longe-term the U.S. unit will find support from a strong U.S. economy.
"It is hard to see why, for economic or policy reasons, the dollar is sliding. Data from Germany remains weak and other core European countries look in pretty poor shape," said ABN AMRO's Norfield.

The start of Japan's new fiscal year was having little immediate impact on dollar/yen rates in Europe and analysts said they expected dollar/yen to remain rangebound ahead of the Bank of Japan's quarterly Tankan corporate survey on Wednesday.
"The market is awaiting the Tankan index...We are expecting a strong survey," said BZW's Turner.

Tokyo stocks ended moderately lower on the first day of the 1997/98 financial year, following Wall Street's tumble and renewed bank woes. The 225-share Nikkei average shed 133.81 points, or 0.74 percent to 17,869.59.
